articles.headline: Lives Crammed Into 240 Square Feet
articles.snippet: Contained within the 9,000 FEMA trailers in Hancock County, Miss., are lives in claustrophobic suspension.
articles.abstract: Contained within the 9,000 FEMA trailers in Hancock County, Miss., are lives in claustrophobic suspension.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAKESHORE, Miss., June 12 — If you were to fly over rural Hancock County here, you would see more than 9,000 of them, white rectangles clumped in sun-bleached parks and scattered in piney woods like pieces of a trashed picket fence. Pick any one, and contained within that FEMA trailer are lives in claustrophobic suspension.

articles.headline: Selling Wave Circles Globe With Losses
articles.snippet: In the United States, stocks drifted in and out of positive territory early in the day but closed down for the third consecutive trading day.
articles.abstract: In the United States, stocks drifted in and out of positive territory early in the day but closed down for the third consecutive trading day.
articles.lead_paragraph: Waves of selling, described by some analysts as panicked, sent stocks and commodities tumbling around the world yesterday.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Martin Fackler

articles.headline: Canada Conservative Gets Aggressive With Big Oil
articles.snippet: By taking on Big Oil, which has developed other offshore fields in Newfoundland and Labrador, premier Danny Williams is taking quite a gamble.
articles.abstract: By taking on Big Oil, which has developed other offshore fields in Newfoundland and Labrador, premier Danny Williams is taking quite a gamble.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, June 13  Danny Williams may be a multimillionaire and a member of the Conservative Party of Canada, but these days he is being compared to a self-proclaimed revolutionary, the Venezuelan president, Hugo Chávez.

articles.headline: Bush Makes Surprise Visit to Iraq to Press Leadership
articles.snippet: President Bush said that the time had come for Iraqis to pull together to save the faltering American-sponsored democracy in Iraq.
articles.abstract: President Bush said that the time had come for Iraqis to pull together to save the faltering American-sponsored democracy in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 13 — President Bush used a surprise visit to Baghdad on Tuesday to tell the country's new leaders that "the fate and future of Iraq is in your hands" and that the time had come for Iraqis to pull together to save the faltering American-sponsored democracy here.
articles.byline: By John F. Burns and Dexter Filkins

articles.headline: A Clash of Newspaper Legacies
articles.snippet: Chandler and McCormick are proud names in newspaper history; now the heirs are locked in a showdown over the direction of the Tribune Company.
articles.abstract: Chandler and McCormick are proud names in newspaper history; now the heirs are locked in a showdown over the direction of the Tribune Company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Harry Chandler of The Los Angeles Times and Colonel Robert R. McCormick of The Chicago Tribune were both towering figures of newspaper publishing in the first half of the 20th century.

articles.headline: Goldman Doubles Its Profit
articles.snippet: Goldman Sachs reported that its earnings more than doubled from a year earlier, but the company failed to impress Wall Street and its stock fell.
articles.abstract: Goldman Sachs reported that its earnings more than doubled from a year earlier, but the company failed to impress Wall Street and its stock fell.
articles.lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs more than doubled its second-quarter profit from a year ago, fueled by strong results in each of its divisions, the company said yesterday.

articles.headline: Israeli Missiles Kill 10 in Gaza
articles.snippet: Also, Israel rejected responsibility for eight deaths on Friday that Palestinians blamed on an errant shell.
articles.abstract: Also, Israel rejected responsibility for eight deaths on Friday that Palestinians blamed on an errant shell.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA, June 13 — Eight Palestinian civilians were killed and more than 40 wounded Tuesday by an Israeli missile strike on Islamic militants riding in a van that Israeli officials said was carrying rockets to launch at Israel. Two men in the van were also killed, including a man the Israelis consider an important rocket maker.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Ian Fisher

articles.headline: The Price of Day Care Can Be High
articles.snippet: Quebec offers universal day care, an audacious idea that recognizes the revolution in women's work over the last 30 years.
articles.abstract: Quebec offers universal day care, an audacious idea that recognizes the revolution in women's work over the last 30 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: THERE is one place in North America where parents of young children don't have to worry about child care. In Quebec, full-time day care costs just $7 a day — Canadian dollars, at that — thanks to a government program aimed at one of the thorniest problems that workers in their 20's, 30's and 40's face.

articles.headline: Hiding in Plain Sight, Google Seeks More Power
articles.snippet: A sprawling new data center in Oregon shows the extraordinary drive to beat Microsoft and Yahoo.
articles.abstract: A sprawling new data center in Oregon shows the extraordinary drive to beat Microsoft and Yahoo.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE DALLES, Ore., June 8 — On the banks of the windswept Columbia River, Google is working on a secret weapon in its quest to dominate the next generation of Internet computing. But it is hard to keep a secret when it is a computing center as big as two football fields, with twin cooling plants protruding four stories into the sky.
articles.byline: By John Markoff and Saul Hansell

articles.headline: Canada Conservative Gets Aggressive With Big Oil

articles.abstract: Danny Williams may be a multimillionaire and a member of the Conservative Party of Canada, but these days he is being compared to a self-proclaimed revolutionary, the Venezuelan president, Hugo Chávez.      Not that Mr. Williams, the premier of Newfoundland and Labrador, minds.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, June 13 - Danny Williams may be a multimillionaire and a member of the Conservative Party of Canada, but these days he is being compared to a self-proclaimed revolutionary, the Venezuelan president, Hugo Chávez.

articles.headline: Goldman Doubles Its Profit
articles.snippet: Goldman Sachs more than doubled its second-quarter profit from a year ago, fueled by strong results in each of its divisions, the company said yesterday.      Like Lehman Brothers a day earlier, when it too reported strong earnings, Goldman failed...
articles.abstract: Goldman Sachs more than doubled its second-quarter profit from a year ago, fueled by strong results in each of its divisions, the company said yesterday.      Like Lehman Brothers a day earlier, when it too reported strong earnings, Goldman failed to impress Wall Street with its good results and its stock fell nearly 4 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs more than doubled its second-quarter profit from a year ago, fueled by strong results in each of its divisions, the company said yesterday.

articles.headline: Lives Crammed Into 240 Square Feet
articles.snippet: If you were to fly over rural Hancock County here, you would see more than 9,000 of them, white rectangles clumped in sun-bleached parks and scattered in piney woods like pieces of a trashed picket fence. Pick any one, and contained within that FE...
articles.abstract: If you were to fly over rural Hancock County here, you would see more than 9,000 of them, white rectangles clumped in sun-bleached parks and scattered in piney woods like pieces of a trashed picket fence. Pick any one, and contained within that FEMA trailer are lives in claustrophobic suspension.     Paulette Shiyou invites you into her family's trailer with a natural hospitality that has remained intact. Her husband, Hugh, offers a can of beer, and her son, Cody, itching to show you his card collection, his rock collection, his pocketknife, kicks off his sneakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAKESHORE, Miss., June 12 - If you were to fly over rural Hancock County here, you would see more than 9,000 of them, white rectangles clumped in sun-bleached parks and scattered in piney woods like pieces of a trashed picket fence. Pick any one, and contained within that FEMA trailer are lives in claustrophobic suspension.

articles.headline: Selling Wave Circles Globe With Losses
articles.snippet: Waves of selling, described by some analysts as panicked, sent stocks and commodities tumbling around the world yesterday.     In the United States, stocks drifted in and out of positive territory early in the day but closed down for the third con...
articles.abstract: Waves of selling, described by some analysts as panicked, sent stocks and commodities tumbling around the world yesterday.     In the United States, stocks drifted in and out of positive territory early in the day but closed down for the third consecutive trading day. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1 percent, the Dow Jones industrial average wiped out its gains for the year and the Nasdaq composite index edged down 0.9 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Waves of selling, described by some analysts as panicked, sent stocks and commodities tumbling around the world yesterday.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Martin Fackler

articles.headline: Hiding in Plain Sight, Google Seeks More Power
articles.snippet: On the banks of the windswept Columbia River, Google is working on a secret weapon in its quest to dominate the next generation of Internet computing. But it is hard to keep a secret when it is a computing center as big as two football fields, wit...
articles.abstract: On the banks of the windswept Columbia River, Google is working on a secret weapon in its quest to dominate the next generation of Internet computing. But it is hard to keep a secret when it is a computing center as big as two football fields, with twin cooling plants protruding four stories into the sky.     The complex, sprawling like an information-age factory, heralds a substantial expansion of a worldwide computing network handling billions of search queries a day and a growing repertory of other Internet services.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE DALLES, Ore., June 8 - On the banks of the windswept Columbia River, Google is working on a secret weapon in its quest to dominate the next generation of Internet computing. But it is hard to keep a secret when it is a computing center as big as two football fields, with twin cooling plants protruding four stories into the sky.
articles.byline: By John Markoff and Saul Hansell

articles.headline: The Price of Day Care Can Be High
articles.snippet: THERE is one place in North America where parents of young children don't have to worry about child care. In Quebec, full-time day care costs just $7 a day -- Canadian dollars, at that -- thanks to a government program aimed at one of the thornies...
articles.abstract: THERE is one place in North America where parents of young children don't have to worry about child care. In Quebec, full-time day care costs just $7 a day -- Canadian dollars, at that -- thanks to a government program aimed at one of the thorniest problems that workers in their 20's, 30's and 40's face.     Starting in 1997, the Quebec Family Policy subsidized day care for 4-year-olds at government-approved centers around the province. By 2000, the program had expanded to cover any child not old enough for kindergarten, all the way down to infants. This is universal day care, an audacious idea that recognizes the revolution in women's work over the last 30 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: THERE is one place in North America where parents of young children don't have to worry about child care. In Quebec, full-time day care costs just $7 a day -- Canadian dollars, at that -- thanks to a government program aimed at one of the thorniest problems that workers in their 20's, 30's and 40's face.

articles.headline: Israeli Missiles Kill 10 in Gaza
articles.snippet: Eight Palestinian civilians were killed and more than 40 wounded Tuesday by an Israeli missile strike on Islamic militants riding in a van that Israeli officials said was carrying rockets to launch at Israel. Two men in the van were also killed, i...
articles.abstract: Eight Palestinian civilians were killed and more than 40 wounded Tuesday by an Israeli missile strike on Islamic militants riding in a van that Israeli officials said was carrying rockets to launch at Israel. Two men in the van were also killed, including a man the Israelis consider an important rocket maker.      The officials said the strike had prevented more of what has been a rising number of Palestinian missile attacks launched from Gaza. But the civilian casualties further inflamed Palestinian rage over eight deaths last week on a beach from what residents said was an errant Israeli shell. Seven of the dead were from one family.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA, June 13 - Eight Palestinian civilians were killed and more than 40 wounded Tuesday by an Israeli missile strike on Islamic militants riding in a van that Israeli officials said was carrying rockets to launch at Israel. Two men in the van were also killed, including a man the Israelis consider an important rocket maker.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Ian Fisher

articles.headline: In Iraq Visit, Bush Seizes on a Step Forward
articles.snippet: In visiting Baghdad on Tuesday, President Bush was trying to deliver a carefully calibrated message to Americans: that Iraq and the administration's strategy there appear to be turning a corner, but troops will not be withdrawn anytime soon.     M...
articles.abstract: In visiting Baghdad on Tuesday, President Bush was trying to deliver a carefully calibrated message to Americans: that Iraq and the administration's strategy there appear to be turning a corner, but troops will not be withdrawn anytime soon.     Mr. Bush could have spoken with Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki by secure videoconference from Camp David. Instead, he embraced Mr. Maliki both figuratively and literally -- at the same time embracing the political reality that Iraq is so central to his presidency that he cannot escape developments there, and must try instead to make the most of any good news.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 13 - In visiting Baghdad on Tuesday, President Bush was trying to deliver a carefully calibrated message to Americans: that Iraq and the administration's strategy there appear to be turning a corner, but troops will not be withdrawn anytime soon.

articles.headline: Bush Makes Surprise Visit to Iraq to Press Leadership
articles.snippet: President Bush used a surprise visit to Baghdad on Tuesday to tell the country's new leaders that ''the fate and future of Iraq is in your hands'' and that the time had come for Iraqis to pull together to save the faltering American-sponsored demo...
articles.abstract: President Bush used a surprise visit to Baghdad on Tuesday to tell the country's new leaders that ''the fate and future of Iraq is in your hands'' and that the time had come for Iraqis to pull together to save the faltering American-sponsored democracy here.     ''My message to the Iraqi people is this: seize the moment,'' Mr. Bush said in a speech to American troops and embassy employees who gave him a rapturous reception in one of the marbled halls of Saddam Hussein's old Republican Palace, now the main American command center in the Green Zone. ''Seize the opportunity to develop a government of, and by, and for the people.''
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 13 - President Bush used a surprise visit to Baghdad on Tuesday to tell the country's new leaders that "the fate and future of Iraq is in your hands" and that the time had come for Iraqis to pull together to save the faltering American-sponsored democracy here.
articles.byline: By John F. Burns and Dexter Filkins

articles.headline: No Rove Charges Over Testimony on C.I.A. Leak
articles.snippet: The decision by a special prosecutor not to bring charges against Karl Rove in the C.I.A. leak case followed months of intense behind-the-scenes maneuvering between the prosecutor, Patrick J. Fitzgerald, and Mr. Rove's lawyer, lawyers in the case ...
articles.abstract: The decision by a special prosecutor not to bring charges against Karl Rove in the C.I.A. leak case followed months of intense behind-the-scenes maneuvering between the prosecutor, Patrick J. Fitzgerald, and Mr. Rove's lawyer, lawyers in the case said.      The move, made public early Tuesday by Mr. Rove's lawyer, Robert D. Luskin, brought a surprise ending to the investigation of Mr. Rove, President Bush's senior adviser. At one point last fall, Mr. Rove seemed close to facing perjury charges over lapses in his early testimony about a conversation with a Time magazine reporter.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 13 - The decision by a special prosecutor not to bring charges against Karl Rove in the C.I.A. leak case followed months of intense behind-the-scenes maneuvering between the prosecutor, Patrick J. Fitzgerald, and Mr. Rove's lawyer, lawyers in the case said.
articles.byline: By David Johnston and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: A Clash of Newspaper Legacies
articles.snippet: Harry Chandler of The Los Angeles Times and Colonel Robert R. McCormick of The Chicago Tribune were both towering figures of newspaper publishing in the first half of the 20th century.     And like many newspaper moguls, both created trusts to saf...
articles.abstract: Harry Chandler of The Los Angeles Times and Colonel Robert R. McCormick of The Chicago Tribune were both towering figures of newspaper publishing in the first half of the 20th century.     And like many newspaper moguls, both created trusts to safeguard the papers they built and the causes they championed. Both wanted to extend their fortunes and influence down through the generations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
